postsData.name:
Cindy Rayfield
Cindy Rayfield
postsData.content:
𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝗧𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗵𝗶𝘀𝗲 𝗣𝗹𝘂𝗻𝗴𝗲? 

Investing in a franchise is a big decision! 

Before you jump in, make sure you ask the franchisor these key questions:

 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘀𝘂𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗜 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗲𝗶𝘃𝗲? A good franchisor will provide comprehensive training and ongoing support to set you up for success. 
 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗽 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗼𝗻𝗴𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝘀? Get a clear picture of the financial investment required. 
 𝗖𝗮𝗻 𝗜 𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗮𝗸 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗲𝘅𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗵𝗶𝘀𝗲𝗲𝘀? Hearing firsthand experiences can give you valuable insights into the franchise system. ️

Doing your homework upfront can save you headaches down the road! Read on to learn more of the key franchising questions you should be asking!
postsData.commentAdded: Great tips! Thorough research and asking the right questions can make all the difference in a successful franchise journey. 🚀 #FranchiseSuccess

postsData.name:
Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
postsData.content:
𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗹𝘆 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗺𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀?

As leaders, it’s easy to get swept up in the whirlwind of deadlines,
meetings, and endless to-dos.

But have you ever stopped to ask yourself:
How often are you truly present in your leadership moments?

Here’s the reality:
Leadership isn’t just about what you say or what you do—it’s about how you show up.

When you’re fully present, your team feels seen, heard, and valued.

This builds trust
fosters collaboration
and creates a healthier
more empowered culture.

But presence goes beyond just being there
it’s showing up with intention, clarity, and emotional awareness.

It’s the difference between hearing and truly listening to your team.

And that makes all the difference.

Pause for a moment:
Are you leading with presence today?

When you lead with mindfulness,
your decision-making improves,
you reduce impulsivity,
and your team will feel your calm even in the chaos.

Take a moment to reflect:
How can you bring more presence into your leadership today?
Let me know in the comments

Found this helpful? 𝗥𝗲𝗽𝗼𝘀𝘁 to share with your network. ️
Followfor more insights on career and leadership growth. ️

comments.commentText:
Bonus #1
Presence is also about modeling balance. When your team sees you handle challenges calmly and prioritize well-being, it gives them permission to do the same.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

comments.commentText:
Bonus #2
Leading with presence means noticing the unspoken. Body language, team dynamics, and the energy in the room can reveal what words sometimes cannot.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

postsData.commentAdded: Great reminder! Being present in leadership truly transforms team dynamics. Lets prioritize mindfulness and connection every day!

postsData.name:
Eric Giguere
Eric Giguere
postsData.content:
Did you know that simplifying your business processes can significantly boost team productivity?

A study by Deloitte highlights that work simplification helps employees overwhelmed by increasing organizational complexity and information overload. Deloitte United States

Clara's business was like a smartphone with too many apps running.

Each new initiative drained resources and slowed performance.

Recognizing the need for change, she took inspiration from app management to 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗺𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝗼𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀:
⭐ Identified essential vs. resource-draining "apps": Focused on initiatives that added real value.
⭐ Activated a "power-saving mode" during critical periods: Prioritized key tasks when it mattered most.
⭐ Scheduled regular system optimizations: Continuously refined processes to maintain efficiency.

The outcome? Clara's business now operates at peak performance
With a 40% improvement in resource utilization and consistently high team energy levels.

𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂?
By embracing similar strategies, you can:
1. Enhance operational efficiency: Streamline processes to reduce waste and improve output.
2. Boost team morale: Eliminate unnecessary tasks, allowing your team to focus on meaningful work.
3. Achieve Performance Consistency: Focus resources on initiatives that drive long-term success.

Reflect on your current operations.

Which "apps" in your business could be closed to enhance performance?

comments.commentText: Keep it simple is definitely my mantra Eric!
Absolutely, but for many people, there are a few steps involved when looking for 'Specific Functionalities', while trying to 'Simplify & Rationalize resources'!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Streamlining operations not only boosts efficiency but also rejuvenates team morale. Time to reassess our apps! 🚀👏

postsData.name:
Rachel Hayden
Rachel Hayden
postsData.content:
Let’s face it: every workplace has challenges. 

But if employees feel they can’t voice concerns to leadership, it’s a red flag.

I’ve seen it firsthand:

- A hiring manager stalls the recruitment process, finding fault with every candidate to avoid someone threatening their position
- Employees afraid to speak up about inefficiencies, worried they’ll lose their jobs
- Teams walking on eggshells because there’s no real open-door policy

And I’ll tell you the result of this:

Constant chaos, burnout, and missed opportunities.

A company is only as good as its people - and its people need to feel heard.

But here’s the fix for you:

Great leadership isn’t about control or ego.

It’s about:

- Listening to your team
- Encouraging honest feedback
- Creating an environment where people feel safe to speak up

Because if you can’t tell your CEO there’s a problem, then that’s a problem in itself.

If you’re a leader who can’t even step away for a vacation without worrying the wheels will fall off, it’s time to rethink your approach.

comments.commentText: Rachel Hayden Very interesting. Thank you for sharing

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Creating a culture of open communication is key. Leaders must prioritize listening to empower their teams and drive success.

postsData.name:
Shulin Lee
Shulin Lee
postsData.content:
7 Worst Types of Colleagues To Keep Close  

(they’ll ruin your career)

Not everyone at work is rooting for your success.

Some colleagues are distractions at best.
And at worst, they’ll pull you down with them.

Here’s who to avoid:

1. The Gossip King/Queen
↳ Thrives on drama and loves to spill secrets.
↳ Remember: If they gossip with you, they’re probably gossiping about you.

2. The Bare Minimum Enthusiast
↳ Coasts - doing just enough to stay out of trouble.
↳ Their lack of drive can drain team morale—and yours.

3. The Chronic Complainer
↳ Always has something to gripe about—deadlines, management, even the office snacks.
↳ Negativity is contagious. Protect your mindset.

4. The Credit Snatcher
↳ Eager to take the glory for work they didn’t do.
↳ Make your contributions visible to the right people.

5. The Over-Sharer
↳ Turns team meetings into their personal therapy session.
↳ Their chaos will derail your focus if you’re not careful.

6. The Passive-Aggressive Saboteur
↳ Smiles to your face but chips away at you behind.
↳ Spot the signs early, set firm boundaries, and don’t let their games go unchecked.

7. The Blame Dodger
↳ Never takes accountability and always finds a scapegoat.
↳ Don’t let their lack of ownership fall on your shoulders.

 You don’t choose your colleagues,
but you do choose who influences your growth.

The people you surround yourself?
Will either elevate you—or drag you down.

Your career deserves better.
Choose wisely.

️ Repost this - your network needs to hear it.
 Followfor more.

comments.commentText: A reminder to always surround yourself with people who uplift, not those who drain your energy or derail your progress. Shulin Lee
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

postsData.content:
The 4 Ws Method: The first W: Why! 

As a leader, your job isn’t just to assign tasks, it’s to 
hashtag
. And the best way to do that? Connect each individual’s
to a bigger vision.

In his best selling book, Start with the WHY,explore and importance of understanding the reason and the driver behind what we are doing.
Also, as
once said: If the 'why' is powerful, the 'how' is easy

So where to start?
 Start with the why: Explain the purpose behind your team’s existence. Why are they here? How does their work align with the company’s vision and culture?
 Link individual whys to the bigger picture: Every team member has their own motivations. Connect their personal goals to the mission of the team and the organization.
 Make the why clear and strong: When the purpose is powerful, motivation follows. Without it, even the best strategies will fall short.

Remember: a team that understands why they’re working together is not just motivated, they’re
.

comments.commentText: Connecting individual goals with a bigger vision can truly inspire teams to perform at their best.

Troy is from Low Stress Options, which provides trading education and resources to business owners. He’s a former Navy nuclear engineer, best-selling author, and world-famous marketing automation specialist with decades of experience running a number of multi-million dollar software and app development, SEO, and business/marketing coaching businesses (whew, that's a mouthful!)

What you'll hear in this episode:

-Troy’s personal experience of growing up in a lower middle-class family and learning from his wealthy host father about the importance of saving and investing.

-What options trading really is.

-How Troy’s students have a 98% win rate, and how his program has been the fastest-growing, most successful program he’s launched in decades.

-How much money you need to start options trading (it’s not as much as you may think!)

-The importance of compliance with regulatory agencies like the FTC and SEC.

postsData.name:
Alex Turnbull
Alex Turnbull
postsData.content:
Do concierge work in an AI age.

→ Skip the automated onboarding
→ Skip the product tutorials
→ Skip the activation flow
→ Skip using self-serve or even PLG

The answer to AI product growth is right in front of you. And that answer is quite simple. Ready?

→ Be there, personally, every step of the way

That's right folks. The answer is high-touch expertise. And the majority of you are scared. You're setting up all these "systems" to do what?

→ To scale faster
→ To reduce friction
→ To automate everything

Why? Because you're afraid to just get in the trenches and do what needs to be done. All along you had to do one simple thing: Talk to your customers directly.

And I don't mean simply posting AI tips here on Twitter.

I mean:

→ Opening 1:1 Slack channels with every VIP customer
→ Personally helping them train their AI agents
→ Optimizing their prompts and workflows
→ Being available for real-time troubleshooting
→ Building trust through hands-on expertise
→ Turning customers into vocal advocates

That beats a fancy onboarding sequence, automated tutorial, or help center ANY day of the week.

It's time to go old school but in a new AI world.

The era of "sign-up-and-go" is dead.

The Concierge Era is here.

Our Q1 goal? 25 customers who absolutely LOVE us.

That's it.

And in 2025, word of mouth from delighted customers wins.

comments.commentText:
May seem like an unpopular opinion in today's day and age but I couldn't agree more! Nothing beats high-touch support especially if retention and deep understanding of customer experience are priorities. It's got us an average customer lifetime of 7 years in a commoditized market.

High touch may increasingly become a competitive advantage with the proliferation of AI-driven automated support.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! High-touch engagement fosters deeper relationships and truly drives product growth. Let’s prioritize connection over automation!

postsData.name:
Michael Ocean
Michael Ocean
postsData.content:
Building a world-class sales org? 
Start with the skills, not the quota.


Had an awesome conversation with(CRO North America at 360Learning) about a fresh take on sales enablement that most revenue leaders miss: Your onboarding shouldn't end after 30 days, and your skills framework should drive performance, not the other way around.


Here's what caught my attention:

- Chris launched a skills ontology program that mapped critical skills, sub-skills, and proficiency levels - making learning measurable and actionable
- Monthly reviews with coaches (frontline managers) created accountability and showed executive buy-in
- The focus shifted from reactive performance management to proactive skill development
- Most importantly? Quota became a lagging indicator, not the north star


In the full episode, we covered:

- Why hiring top performers from tech giants doesn't guarantee success
- How AI is transforming enablement and course creation (3-minute course, anyone?)
- The power of practice before execution
- Building a culture of continuous learning in a high-growth environment


Want to hear more about building a learning-first sales culture?

Check out the full conversation in the comments

comments.commentText:
Focusing on skills over quotas is a game-changer. This approach fosters true growth within teams. How crucial is setting learning objectives?  
hashtag

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights on prioritizing skills over quotas! Love the focus on continuous learning and measurable development in sales enablement.

postsData.name:
Colby Wegter
Colby Wegter
postsData.content:
If you've told yourself, do more = earn more, read this:

We tell ourselves that we should:

→ Diversify
→ Do the small thing now (b/c it'll be big later)
→ Not miss this "once-in-a-lifetime" opportunity

It's all crap.

We've been trained to get more we need to do more.

False.

Check this:

Jacob was at:

→ $50K months
→ On meetings 8 hours per day
→ Working 12-hour days
→ 6 days per week

Then he did less.

And in 30 days, he:

→ Hit a $75K month
→ Took 4 hours of meetings per week
→ 6-hour days
→ 4 or 5 days per week

More isn't better. It's worse. Way f**king worse.

postsData.name:
Cory Blumenfeld
Cory Blumenfeld
postsData.content:
Big decisions are hard.
But, we’ve all been there...

You’re an entrepreneur staring down a big decision,
It’s overwhelming,
It’s stressful,
It keeps you up at night.

And as humans,
As dreamers,
As leaders...

Our instinct is to replay every scenario,
We overanalyze,
We second-guess ourselves, over and over.

But here’s the thing,
Those looping thoughts we all have?
They’re totally normal.

Here are 7 thoughts most entrepreneurs have when faced with a big decision,
And how to shift them:

1️⃣ "What if I’m wrong?"
2️⃣ "Will people think I’m crazy?"
3️⃣ "I don’t have enough information."
4️⃣ "I don’t want to let everyone down."
5️⃣ "Am I good enough to pull this off?"
6️⃣ "This is going to cost too much money."
7️⃣ "I’m never right... why is this any different?"

Sound familiar?
It’s normal.

Big decisions are scary cuz they matter.
They push us out of our comfort zones and force us to take risks.

But here’s the thing...

No matter what you choose,
The fact that you’re even here making this call,
It’s proof that you’re doing the hard stuff.

And that’s what it’s all about.



---

️ Repost to help someone push past self-doubt today.

 Followfor more entrepreneurial insights and motivation.

I’m on a mission to inspire 1M everyday ppl to start their biz and find their voice in the process.

comments.commentText: 5, ‘Am I good enough to pull this off?’ is something every entrepreneur faces. It’s the inner battle that comes with growth. What’s one decision you’ve made that pushed you out of your comfort zone and led to success?

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing the uncertainty of big decisions is what truly sets us apart as entrepreneurs. Keep pushing forward! 🚀

postsData.content:
𝗔𝗻 𝗢𝗽𝗲𝗻 𝗟𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝟭𝟭𝟵𝘁𝗵 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗴𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀: 𝗟𝗲𝘁’𝘀 𝗢𝘃𝗲𝗿-𝗜𝗻𝗻𝗼𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗲, 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗢𝘃𝗲𝗿-𝗟𝗲𝗴𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗔𝗜 

America’s greatest strength has always been innovation, not bureaucracy. As AI rapidly evolves, Congress must ensure that legislation fosters responsible growth rather than stifling competition and pushing innovation overseas.

In my open letter to Congress, I outline why AI policy should prioritize 𝗮𝗱𝗮𝗽𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗼𝗹𝗼𝗴𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽—without imposing unnecessary constraints. A case law-driven approach and state-level experimentation can provide the flexibility needed to govern AI effectively while keeping America at the forefront of global innovation.

Read the full piece here:

What do you think—how should Congress strike the right balance between AI legislation and innovation?

comments.commentText: Love this

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Its crucial for Congress to foster an environment where innovation thrives while ensuring responsible AI use. Adapting policy is key!

postsData.name:
Owen Sammarone 🚀
Owen Sammarone 🚀
postsData.content:
Think your company's brand is enough?

Here's what I learned after helping 500+ business leaders build their personal brands:

When Microsoft's Satya Nadella posts → 10x more engagement than Microsoft's corporate account.

Why? People trust people, not logos.

Your audience wants to see:

- The strategist behind the strategy
- The visionary behind the vision
- The leader behind the success

Real example: One of my clients, Dan, was stuck relying solely on his company's brand and in-person events.

After building his personal brand on LinkedIn:
→ Added $13k+ in recurring revenue
→ Generated $50k in consulting deals
→ Created multiple revenue streams

The truth? Your personal brand isn't competing with your company brand. It's amplifying it.

Every post from a founder carries more weight than a corporate message.
Every insight you share builds trust that logos can't create.
Every story you tell adds humanity that marketing can't buy.

Stop hiding behind your company logo.
Start building your magnetic personal brand.

comments.commentText: People skills are a rare commodity in todays world. Your personality isthe greatest differentiator between you and everyone else.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely spot on! Personal brands add depth and trust that corporate messages cant. Time to shine and amplify our stories! 🌟 #PersonalBranding

postsData.name:
Faruk Arslan
Faruk Arslan
postsData.content:
NVIDIA stocks just went down 11%. This isn't just a dip. 
 They lost $400 billion in value. 

Is DeepSeek from China the real game behind this?

Looks that way.
On track for a record-breaking loss.
The biggest one-day fall of any company in history.

Why?

DeepSeek's influence is powerful and undeniable.
It challenges US tech dominance.

Why is it a threat?
It's not just economic impact.
It's a geopolitical move.

Puts US tech giants on edge.
China's tech rise isn't slowing down.

DeepSeek is a prime example.
It offers competition that traditional markets can't ignore.

US tech must stay vigilant.
DeepSeek indicates rising innovation in unexpected places.

This challenges the security and influence of US tech.
And underscores the impact of global competition.

The cost of complacency is high.
Adapting isn't an option.
It's essential.

Will NVIDIA bounce back?
Time will tell.

But for now, DeepSeek shows a shift in the tech landscape.

 And this wake-up call is loud and clear.
postsData.commentAdded: A significant wake-up call for US tech! DeepSeeks rise highlights the need for innovation and vigilance in a rapidly changing landscape. 🔍📈

postsData.name:
Roki Hasan
Roki Hasan
postsData.content:
68% of B2B companies struggle to generate qualified leads consistently, leaving millions in potential revenue untapped. (McKinsey)

The $1,500 insight in this video triggered a powerful visual reminder for me.

Here's what keeps me up at night:

Seeing brilliant founders with game-changing solutions struggle to reach their ideal clients.
Your innovative product? Your transformative service? They mean nothing if the right people aren't discovering them.

This is why I've dedicated my business to solving the most critical scaling challenge: consistent, qualified lead generation. Not just filling your pipeline, but engineering predictable growth that lets you:

- Focus on what you do best: innovating and leading

- Scale without the constant anxiety of feast-or-famine cycles

- Build a sustainable engine for market dominance

I've watched countless visionaries transform their market position once they solved this fundamental challenge.

One tech startup went from constantly chasing leads to having their pick of premium clients. A consultancy gained significant revenue growth in 6 months with the same team size.

The real question isn't whether you can afford to solve your lead generation challenges. It's whether you can afford not to.

Ready to turn your market-changing vision into market-dominating reality?

Let's talk about how systematic lead generation can fuel your next phase of growth.

comments.commentText: Seeing these results makes me think of our failed attempt at building predictable growth. What’s the #1 mistake you see?

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely spot on! Consistent lead generation can be a game-changer for visionary founders. Excited to see more businesses thrive! 🚀

postsData.name:
Shail Khiyara
Shail Khiyara
postsData.content:
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗜 𝗜𝗻𝗱𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘆 𝗜𝘀 𝗕𝗲𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗗𝗶𝘀𝗿𝘂𝗽𝘁𝗲𝗱—𝗔𝗻𝗱 𝗧𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗮 𝗚𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗲𝗿𝗮 𝗼𝗳 𝗲𝘅𝗰𝗹𝘂𝘀𝗶𝘃𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗶𝗻 𝗔𝗜 𝗶𝘀 𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿.

𝗗𝗲𝗲𝗽𝗦𝗲𝗲𝗸, an open-source disruptor, is rewriting the rules of the AI market. By making state-of-the-art models like 𝗗𝗲𝗲𝗽𝗦𝗲𝗲𝗸-𝗥𝟭 freely accessible, they’ve done something the industry giants never expected: they’ve democratized AI.

𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝘆 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀:

 𝗖𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗥𝗲𝘃𝗼𝗹𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: DeepSeek’s models are 25–30x cheaper per token than proprietary ones like OpenAI’s. Advanced AI is no longer reserved for companies with deep pockets—it’s now within reach for startups, SMBs, and innovators worldwide.

 𝗜𝗻𝗻𝗼𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗹𝗼𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻: Open-source isn’t just about saving money. It invites collaboration, experimentation, and a wave of innovation that closed ecosystems can’t match.

 𝗚𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗜𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗰𝘁: This shift is empowering regions, industries, and businesses that were previously priced out of the AI revolution.

𝗦𝗼, 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗼𝗳 𝘂𝘀?

1. 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗜 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝗺𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝗱𝗮𝗽𝘁 𝗼𝗿 𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗸 𝗶𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗹𝗲𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲. The market is now demanding hybrid strategies that balance affordability with premium capabilities.

2. 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗻𝗼 𝗲𝘅𝗰𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗶𝘁 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀. The tools to innovate are now accessible, and those who fail to adopt AI will be left behind.

3. 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘀 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗶𝗿 𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗳𝗼𝗹𝗶𝗼𝘀. The future lies with companies that combine efficiency, accessibility, and differentiation—not just scale or exclusivity.

The democratization of AI is breaking barriers and leveling the playing field—and we’re just getting started.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗾𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝗶𝗳 𝗔𝗜 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱—𝗶𝘁’𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗮𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝘄𝗲 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗶𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗽𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗲.

How are you preparing for this shift? Let’s discuss.
Watch for more on this topic in my next post. ‍

postsData.name:
Michael Kainatsky
Michael Kainatsky
postsData.content:
A quick LinkedIn guide to being human in 2025. 


Last year, I spent a lot of hours here.

The point of this platform is not to always be on this platform.

That’s changed of course with the gurus pushing the optics agenda.

LinkedIn was created to be a networking site.

A place to actually meet people.

Yes, you can have conversations in the comments and DMs.

But that’s not where relationships are built, it’s where they’re started.

At least that’s what it used to be before AI took everything over.

Have real conversations on the phone, zoom, text, meet for coffee, whatever.

Just take it off the platform as soon as you can.

We’re digital avatars.

If you get a lot of DMs, I know it can be annoying with all the pitches.

Do yourself a favor and read all your messages.

You’re hitting the “not Interested” auto reply on some amazing people.

Trust me, I became friends with and even started to mentor someone

Who pitched slapped me!

You know what, here’s a great kid!

I read every single message I get, and reply to them all.

If each of us works to humanize this platform, it will actually become

More human!

We’re all here for mostly the same things.

So what if you get pitch slapped?

Don’t you expect that to happen here, anyway?

Is it difficult to say no thank you after reading it?

So many people are not reading posts, but pretending to

and then giving AI comments.

That is a hell of a lot worse than any pitch slap you’ll ever get.

Why?

Because the pitch slappers are honest about their intentions.

Let’s not all complain about the AI bots taking over

and then go and act like them.

Yours truthfully,

comments.commentText: This is my wish as well. And we all make these mistakes. I just got disconnected by a person who felt I was promoting to them when I sent a DM to them asking for their thoughts and inputs. What I should have done is just reached out to her asking if she could take 15 minutes to have a video chat with me. What I realized is I was not being relatable to her. Sometimes we need to re-learn these lessons and be reminded of how we would all want to be treated as people not as transactions.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Its all about building genuine connections. Lets prioritize real conversations and bring the human touch back to LinkedIn!
